<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Good morning. </strong>These are certainly unusual times. The NBA is suspended, Italy is locked down, Tom Hanks has coronavirus, and many of you are currently reading this in PJs.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">We're gonna get through this.</strong> And we want readers to know that now more than ever we are laser-focused on bringing you the most important business news every morning. If there’s ever any way we can be more useful to you, our inbox is always open. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Have a great day, and remember: When videoconferencing, the mute button is your friend.</p>

<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px">
<span>
</span><span><strong style="color:#000">COVID-19: </strong></span><span>The World Health Organization has officially declared coronavirus a “</span><span><a href="https://apnews.com/52e12ca90c55b6e0c398d134a2cc286e?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">pandemic</a></span><span>.” That sounds alarming, but the agency also said countries can mitigate the impacts if they “detect, test, treat, isolate, trace and mobilize their people in the response."</span>
</li>
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px">
<span>
</span><span><strong style="color:#000">U.S. economy: </strong></span><span>Many economists are </span><span><a href="https://www.reuters.com/article/us-health-coronavirus-usa-recession/coronavirus-shifts-u-s-recession-debate-from-if-to-what-shape-idUSKBN20Y33B?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">no longer debating</a></span><span> </span><span><em>whether</em></span><span> we’ll have a recession because of the coronavirus...the questions now are 1) how bad will the recession be and 2) how quickly can we recover.</span>
</li>
</ul>

<!--[if !mso ]><! -- -->
<div class="c6 " style="margin-bottom:7px">
<!-- <![endif]-->
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<th class="card" style="text-align:left;font-weight:400;font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#333;display:block;background-color:#fff;border-radius:15px;border:1px solid #e6e6e6;border-collapse:collapse;box-shadow:none;margin-bottom:0px">
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding: 15px;">
<h3 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#1c7ff2;font-weight:700;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:0">
ECONOMY
</h3>
<h1 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:24px;color:#333;font-weight:700;margin-bottom:0;line-height:26px;margin-top:8px">
<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2020/03/11/trump-congressional-leaders-negotiate-stimulus-measures?email={{profile.email}}" target="_blank" style="color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;">
<font color="#000000">
Government Stimulus: All About the Stiming
</font></a>
</h1>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
<img alt="Trump giving speech in Oval Office" style="display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;" width="670" class="story-header-image" src="https://dlp31coh2a67q.cloudfront.net/eyJrZXkiOiJ1cGxvYWRzL21lZGl1bS9hc3NldC8xODMvdHJ1bXBfb3ZhbF9vZmZpY2UuanBnIiwiYnVja2V0Ijoib3Nsby1wcm9kdWN0aW9uIiwiZWRpdHMiOnsicmVzaXplIjp7IndpZHRoIjoxMDAwLCJoZWlnaHQiOm51bGx9fX0=">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px;">
<small><em>Doug Mills-Pool/Getty Images</em></small>
</p>
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding:15px">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Investors, airlines, cruise operators, and newsletter writers who miss their work sweaters were watching President Trump for any news of a stimulus measure to cushion the economic impact of the coronavirus. </p>
<ul style="margin-top:0;padding-left:30px">
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>Of course, the most important thing is to contain the virus’s spread. But...that’s for health experts, not economists. </span></li>
</ul>
<h2 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:19px;font-weight:700;color:#000;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;margin-right:0;margin-left:0">What Trump said</h2>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">In a brief Oval Office address last night, President Trump laid out <a href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/03/11/world/coronavirus-news.html?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">his plan</a> to respond to the crisis: </p>
<ul style="margin-top:0;padding-left:30px">
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>He's restricting some travel from Europe (minus the U.K.) for 30 days.</span></li>
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>The IRS will be instructed to push back the April 15 tax payment deadline.</span></li>
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>The president also called for low interest loans for small businesses and a payroll tax cut from Congress. </span></li>
</ul>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Investors were...not impressed. Futures tied to major stock indexes tanked after the speech, which did not mention any aggressive actions like infusions for suffering industries or paid sick leave. The White House also had to correct some of Trump's statements following his address.  </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Zoom out: </strong><a href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/03/11/business/dealbook/coronavirus-bailouts.html?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">There is precedent</a> for government bailouts in times of crisis. The U.S. government provided $15 billion to airlines after 9/11, $700 billion to banks to army-crawl through the 2008 financial crisis, and $17 billion to automakers just after that. </p>
<ul style="margin-top:0;padding-left:30px">
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>Those episodes show us that timeliness is key. In 2008, Congress dragged its feet until it was almost too late, friend of the Brew and bailout expert Andrew Ross Sorkin writes. </span></li>
</ul>
<h2 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:19px;font-weight:700;color:#000;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;margin-right:0;margin-left:0">Will the administration announce something more?</h2>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">We just don’t know. Fed Chair Jerome Powell recently met with President Trump and Treasury Secretary Steve Mnuchin. Powell has already cut interest rates and indicated he’s willing to keep up the slashing.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">But it’s important to remember a pandemic is different from a financial crisis—bargain-basement interest rates can help keep businesses afloat, but the “social distancing” measures recommended by health officials mean canceling events and avoiding crowded places, which will curb spending. Interest rates can’t fix that. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Looking ahead...</strong>the U.S. House will vote on a stimulus package compiled by the Democrats (who hold a majority) today.</p>

<!-- <![endif]-->
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<th class="card" style="text-align:left;font-weight:400;font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#333;display:block;background-color:#fff;border-radius:15px;border:1px solid #e6e6e6;border-collapse:collapse;box-shadow:none;margin-bottom:0px">
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding: 15px;">
<h3 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#1c7ff2;font-weight:700;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:0">
SPORTS
</h3>
<h1 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:24px;color:#333;font-weight:700;margin-bottom:0;line-height:26px;margin-top:8px">
<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2020/03/11/ncaa-bans-fans-2020-tournament-coronavirus-concerns?email={{profile.email}}" target="_blank" style="color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;">
<font color="#000000">
March Sadness
</font></a>
</h1>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
<img alt="Empty basketball stadium" style="display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;" width="670" class="story-header-image" src="https://dlp31coh2a67q.cloudfront.net/eyJrZXkiOiJ1cGxvYWRzL21lZGl1bS9hc3NldC8xODIvZW1wdHlfYmFza2V0YmFsbF9zdGFkaXVtLmpwZyIsImJ1Y2tldCI6Im9zbG8tcHJvZHVjdGlvbiIsImVkaXRzIjp7InJlc2l6ZSI6eyJ3aWR0aCI6MTAwMCwiaGVpZ2h0IjpudWxsfX19">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px;">
<small><em>Ronald Martinez/Getty Images</em></small>
</p>
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding:15px">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Yesterday, sports officially stopped being an "escape" from the problems facing the world.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">The NBA <a href="https://www.espn.com/nba/story/_/id/28887560/nba-suspends-season-further-notice-player-tests-positive-coronavirus?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">suspended the season</a> after Rudy Gobert, a Utah Jazz player, reportedly tested positive for coronavirus. In a statement, the league said it <span>"will use this hiatus to determine next steps for moving forward in regard to the coronavirus pandemic." </span></p>
<ul style="margin-top:0;padding-left:30px">
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span><span>We're in <a href="https://www.cbssports.com/nba/news/coronavirus-update-nba-suspends-season-after-utah-jazz-player-tests-positive-for-covid-19/?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">uncharted territory</a> here. The NBA has billions in revenue at stake through TV deals, ticket sales, merch, and more. No one is quite sure what's going to happen next, including commissioner Adam Silver. </span></span></li>
</ul>
<h2 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:19px;font-weight:700;color:#000;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;margin-right:0;margin-left:0">Basketball couldn't catch a break</h2>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">The NCAA men’s and women’s basketball tournaments will be played <a href="https://www.cnbc.com/2020/03/11/ncaa-march-madness-basketball-games-will-be-closed-to-public-spectators.html?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">without public fans</a> this year out of coronavirus concerns. “Only essential staff and limited family attendance” will be allowed, said NCAA President Mark Emmert.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Zoom out: </strong>The Division I men’s basketball tournament generates $868 million annually on <a href="https://www.foxbusiness.com/sports/coronavirus-ncaa-basketball-revenue-march-madness-impact?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">television and marketing rights alone</a>, the vast majority of the NCAA’s yearly revenue. </p>
<ul style="margin-top:0;padding-left:30px">
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>CBS and Turner Sports said they support the decision and intend to fully produce and cover the event.</span></li>
</ul>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Bottom line, via USA Today: </strong>“The decision to move March Madness behind closed doors represents a <a href="https://www.usatoday.com/story/sports/ncaab/2020/03/11/ncaa-tournament-fans-banned-due-to-coronavirus-concerns/5024027002/?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">new frontier</a> of sorts for American sports, which have never seen an event of this size and scope take place without fans present.”</p>

MARKETS
</h3>
<h1 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:24px;color:#333;font-weight:700;margin-bottom:0;line-height:26px;margin-top:8px">
<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2020/03/11/dow-enters-bear-market-sp-next?email={{profile.email}}" target="_blank" style="color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;">
<font color="#000000">
Dow Dow Dow Dow Down
</font></a>
</h1>

<!--[if mso]>

<![endif]-->
<!--[if !mso]>--><!-- -->
<img class="story-header-image" alt="Bear waving" style="display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;" width="670" src="https://oslo-production.s3.amazonaws.com/uploads/medium/asset/180/bear_market.gif">
<!--<![endif]-->
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px;">
<small><em>Giphy</em></small>
</p>
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding:15px">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">After 11 years, the longest-ever bull market in stocks appears to be nearing the end. If coronavirus put it near the edge, fears over <a href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/03/11/business/stock-market-today.html?action=click&module=Spotlight&pgtype=Homepage&utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">long-term economic implications</a> tipped it over.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Yesterday, the Dow fell 5.9%, <a href="https://www.wsj.com/articles/global-markets-calmer-after-two-hectic-days-11583899913?mod=breakingnews&utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">putting it in a bear market</a> (down at least 20% from its recent high). The S&P 500 might not be far behind, closing just 33 points away from a bear designation of its own.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">How about a little color? </strong>Hope you like red. </p>
<ul style="margin-top:0;padding-left:30px">
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>29 of the 30 stocks in the Dow ended Wednesday lower. </span></li>
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>All 11 sectors of the S&P were at least 10% off their 52-week highs during Wednesday trading. </span></li>
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px">
<span>Since 1915, the </span><span><a href="https://twitter.com/ReformedBroker/status/1237323133109047296?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">average amount of days</a></span><span> it’s taken for stocks to go from peak → bear territory is 255. The Dow took 28 this time. We’ve had milk in the fridge for longer.</span>
</li>
</ul>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">+ Wondering how else coronavirus is impacting the markets?</strong> Morning Brew’s <em>Business Casual </em>podcast just recorded a special episode to break down what’s happening, why it matters, and what comes next—with the Brew’s Kinsey Grant and markets expert Downtown Josh Brown.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Listen here:</strong> <a href="https://link.chtbl.com/joshbrowncoronavirus_apple?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">Apple</a> / <a href="https://link.chtbl.com/joshbrowncoronavirus_spotify?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">Spotify</a> / <a href="https://link.chtbl.com/joshbrowncoronavirus_all?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">everywhere else</a></p>

</table>
<img alt="A Harvard University building" style="display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;" width="670" class="story-header-image" src="https://dlp31coh2a67q.cloudfront.net/eyJrZXkiOiJ1cGxvYWRzL21lZGl1bS9hc3NldC8xNzkvaGFydmFyZF91bml2ZXJzaXR5LnBuZyIsImJ1Y2tldCI6Im9zbG8tcHJvZHVjdGlvbiIsImVkaXRzIjp7InJlc2l6ZSI6eyJ3aWR0aCI6MTAwMCwiaGVpZ2h0IjpudWxsfX19">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px;">
<small><em>Harvard University</em></small>
</p>
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding:15px">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Colleges and universities across the U.S. are <a href="https://www.axios.com/universities-close-coronavirus-73fb30be-126d-4553-a0fc-8ae1f1d96ccd.html?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">deploying measures</a> to limit the spread of coronavirus. </p>
<ul style="margin-top:0;padding-left:30px">
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>For many students, spring break starts tomorrow, which means many of them will be traveling both domestically and internationally. Schools are trying to avoid importing COVID-19 via flights back to campus.</span></li>
</ul>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">On Tuesday, Harvard <a href="https://www.axios.com/what-happens-when-harvard-closes-3652393f-6b99-4869-bef1-1b22765410e5.html?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">asked students</a> to move out by this weekend, leaving students pondering how to tell friends they’ve been kicked off campus without sounding obnoxious. Stanford and the University of Washington were among the first to suspend in-person classes. </p>
<ul style="margin-top:0;padding-left:30px">
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>UW shifted its 50,000 students to online-only courses through March 20, as many schools in Europe and Asia have already done. </span></li>
</ul>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Plus, schools are axing university-sponsored international trips, sending mildly alarming preparedness messages, and preparing for total shutdowns if a student or faculty infection is confirmed.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Bottom line: </strong>Muted activity in college towns could take a substantial economic toll. Everything from prospective student visits to athletic tournaments fuels their financial health, <a href="https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2020-03-10/college-towns-to-clear-out-with-virus-upending-local-businesses?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">Bloomberg notes</a>.</p>

<div class="c6 " style="margin-bottom:7px">
<!-- <![endif]-->
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<th class="card" style="text-align:left;font-weight:400;font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#333;display:block;background-color:#fff;border-radius:15px;border:1px solid #e6e6e6;border-collapse:collapse;box-shadow:none;margin-bottom:0px">
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding: 15px;">
<h3 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#1c7ff2;font-weight:700;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:0">
ENTERTAINMENT
</h3>
<h1 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:24px;color:#333;font-weight:700;margin-bottom:0;line-height:26px;margin-top:8px">
<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2020/03/11/global-entertainment-market-hits-milestone-2019?email={{profile.email}}" target="_blank" style="color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;">
<font color="#000000">
The Entertainment Industry Has a Home Field Advantage
</font></a>
</h1>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
<!--[if mso]>
<img alt="Bong says he's going to drink at the Oscars " style="display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;" width="670" height=362 src="https://oslo-production.s3.amazonaws.com/uploads/medium/asset/178/bong.gif">
<![endif]-->
<!--[if !mso]>--><!-- -->
<img class="story-header-image" alt="Bong says he's going to drink at the Oscars " style="display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;" width="670" src="https://oslo-production.s3.amazonaws.com/uploads/medium/asset/178/bong.gif">
<!--<![endif]-->
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px;">
<small><em>Giphy</em></small>
</p>
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding:15px">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">The global entertainment market, from the box office to in-home streaming, surpassed $100 billion in annual revenue for the <a href="https://variety.com/2020/digital/news/global-entertainment-industry-surpasses-100-billion-for-the-first-time-ever-1203529990/?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">first time ever</a> last year, according to the Motion Picture Association of America (MPAA). </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">But like <em>Les Mis</em>, the MPAA report highlights the differences between the <a href="https://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/fueled-by-streaming-global-entertainment-market-hit-record-100-billion-2019-1283800?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">haves and the have-nots</a>.</p>
<ul style="margin-top:0;padding-left:30px">
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>Money spent on home and mobile viewing jumped 14% to $58.8 billion. </span></li>
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>But the box office barely eked out a 1% gain with $42.2 billion in sales. While overseas moviegoers turned out in record numbers (crossing $30 billion in ticket sales for the first time), sales in the U.S. and Canada fell over 4% to $11.4 billion.</span></li>
</ul>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">The forecast this year? Another case of red and black. With coronavirus fears spreading across the globe, <a href="https://www.axios.com/global-entertainment-market-record-36bef1b3-68cf-49c0-a0be-f611d5dccd11.html?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">out-of-home entertainment</a> will likely take a beating—analysts already predict the box office will lose $5 billion in 2020. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">At the same time, in-home entertainment is predicted to skyrocket even further...because we all know “working from home” roughly translates to “rewatching <em>The Sopranos</em>.”</p>

<tr>

<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<th class="card" style="text-align:left;font-weight:400;font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#333;display:block;background-color:#fff;border-radius:15px;border:1px solid #e6e6e6;border-collapse:collapse;box-shadow:none;margin-bottom:0px">
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding: 15px;">
<h3 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#1c7ff2;font-weight:700;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:0">
BEVERAGE
</h3>
<h1 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:24px;color:#333;font-weight:700;margin-bottom:0;line-height:26px;margin-top:8px">
<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2020/03/11/pepsi-buying-energy-drink-rockstar-39-billion?email={{profile.email}}" target="_blank" style="color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;">
<font color="#000000">
Because Pepsi Doesn't Have Enough Caffeine Already...
</font></a>
</h1>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
<img alt="Pepsi can with up arrow" style="display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;" width="670" class="story-header-image" src="https://dlp31coh2a67q.cloudfront.net/eyJrZXkiOiJ1cGxvYWRzL21lZGl1bS9hc3NldC8xNzcvcGVwc2lfY2FuLmpwZyIsImJ1Y2tldCI6Im9zbG8tcHJvZHVjdGlvbiIsImVkaXRzIjp7InJlc2l6ZSI6eyJ3aWR0aCI6MTAwMCwiaGVpZ2h0IjpudWxsfX19">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px;">
<small><em>Francis Scialabba</em></small>
</p>
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding:15px">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">PepsiCo will spend $3.9 billion to buy <a href="https://www.ft.com/content/6f73921e-638b-11ea-b3f3-fe4680ea68b5?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">energy drink brand Rockstar</a> in order to 1) get Nickelback stuck in your head and 2) expand market share in the fast-growing energy beverage space.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">This is a familiar strategy for brands that once sponsored games of truth-or-I-dare-you-to-mix-Coke-and-Hi-C. As sodas fall out of favor with sugarphobic consumers, the Pepsis and Cokes of the world are investing in beverage alternatives like teas, waters, and energy drinks.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Big picture: </strong>Neither Pepsi nor Coke currently owns a major brand in the energy drink category—which is slated to grow to more than $80 billion over the next five years.</p>
<ul style="margin-top:0;padding-left:30px">
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>Rockstar is the No. 3 contender in the U.S. energy drink market, behind Red Bull, which sold a can for every person on earth last year, and Monster, which counts Coke as an investor.</span></li>
</ul>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Pepsi’s distributed Rockstar in North America since 2009, a deal its CFO says <a href="https://www.cnbc.com/2020/03/11/pepsico-to-acquire-energy-drink-maker-rockstar-energy-in-a-3point85-billion-deal.html?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">limited Pepsi’s ability</a> to partner with other energy brands. Nearly $4 billion later, it can again target those deals.</p>

<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding-top: 12px;">
<a href="https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.morningbrew.com%2Fdaily%2Fstories%2F2020%2F03%2F11%2Fpepsi-buying-energy-drink-rockstar-39-billion" target="_blank" rel="noopener" style="text-decoration: none;" class="">

</a>

<th class="card" style="text-align:left;font-weight:400;font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#333;display:block;background-color:#fff;border-radius:15px;border:1px solid #e6e6e6;border-collapse:collapse;box-shadow:none;margin-bottom:0px">
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding: 15px;">
<h3 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#1c7ff2;font-weight:700;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:0">
WHAT ELSE IS BREWING
</h3>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding-right:15px;padding-bottom:15px;padding-left:15px;padding-top:0px">
<ul style="margin-top:0;padding-left:30px">
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px">
<span>
</span><span><a href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/03/11/nyregion/harvey-weinstein-sentencing.html?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">Harvey Weinstein</a></span><span> was sentenced to 23 years in prison for sexual assault.</span>
</li>
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px">
<span>
</span><span><a href="https://www.reuters.com/article/us-health-coronavirus-amtrak/amtrak-says-bookings-plunge-is-set-to-lose-several-hundred-million-dollars-on-coronavirus-fears-idUSKBN20Y36G?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">Amtrak</a></span><span> said it would lose hundreds of millions of dollars and that bookings have fallen 50% since the beginning of the outbreak. </span>
</li>
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px">
<span>
</span><span><a href="https://www.axios.com/coronavirus-supply-chains-china-46d82a0f-9f52-4229-840a-936822ddef41.html?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">Coronavirus</a></span><span> has disrupted the supply chains of nearly 75% of U.S. companies, per a new ISM survey.</span>
</li>
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span><span><a href="https://www.cnbc.com/2020/03/11/washington-state-bans-large-events-to-contain-the-coronavirus-outbreak.html?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">Officials banned</a> large gatherings in San Francisco and the Seattle area in an attempt to control the coronavirus.</span></span></li>
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span><span><a href="https://www.usatoday.com/story/entertainment/tv/2020/03/10/coronavirus-concerns-jeopardy-wheel-of-fortune-nix-live-audience/5012683002/?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">Numerous TV shows</a>, such as <em>Wheel of Fortune </em>and <em>Jeopardy!</em>, are now filming without live audiences. </span></span></li>
</ul>
</td>
</tr>

<!-- <![endif]-->
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<th class="card" style="text-align:left;font-weight:400;font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#333;display:block;background-color:#fff;border-radius:15px;border:1px solid #e6e6e6;border-collapse:collapse;box-shadow:none;margin-bottom:0px">
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding: 15px;">
<h3 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#1c7ff2;font-weight:700;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:0">
BREW'S BETS
</h3>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding-right:15px;padding-bottom:15px;padding-left:15px;padding-top:0px">
<ul style="margin-top:0;padding-left:30px">

<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Picture this:</strong> You’re interviewing a promising job candidate on Skype when...your husband walks behind you wearing his boxers. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">The year is 2020, #SocialDistancing is trending on Twitter, and more people are working from home every day. That’s resulted in some strange situations for our friends and colleagues, from finding out your boss has a “Live, laugh, love” poster to realizing your neighbor blasts EDM at 11 in the morning.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Bottom line: </strong>If you are working from home and things are getting weird...<a href="https://morningbrewdaily.typeform.com/to/paI0M3?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">share your stories here</a>. “detect, test, treat, isolate, trace and mobilize their people in the response.\"\u003c/span\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\n\u003cspan\u003e\n\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eU.S. economy: \u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003eMany economists are \u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e\u003ca style=\"font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#1c7ff2;font-weight:700;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:0\"\u003e\nECONOMY \n\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003ch1 style=\"font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:24px;color:#333;font-weight:700;margin-bottom:0;line-height:26px;margin-top:8px\"\u003e\n\u003ca href=\"https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2020/03/11/trump-congressional-leaders-negotiate-stimulus-measures?email={{profile.email}}\" target=\"_blank\" style=\"color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;\"\u003e\n\u003cfont color=\"#000000\"\u003e\nGovernment Stimulus: All About the Stiming\n\u003c/font\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\n\u003c/h1\u003e\n\u003c/td\u003e\n\u003c/tr\u003e\n\u003c/table\u003e\n\u003cimg alt=\"Trump giving speech in Oval Office\" style=\"display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;\" width=\"670\" class=\"story-header-image\" src=\"https://dlp31coh2a67q.cloudfront.net/eyJrZXkiOiJ1cGxvYWRzL21lZGl1bS9hc3NldC8xODMvdHJ1bXBfb3ZhbF9vZmZpY2UuanBnIiwiYnVja2V0Ijoib3Nsby1wcm9kdWN0aW9uIiwiZWRpdHMiOnsicmVzaXplIjp7IndpZHRoIjoxMDAwLCJoZWlnaHQiOm51bGx9fX0=\"\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px;\"\u003e\n\u003csmall\u003e\u003cem\u003eDoug Mills-Pool/Getty Images\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/small\u003e\n\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ctable width=\"100%\" cellpadding=\"0\" cellspacing=\"0\" border=\"0\" style=\"border-collapse: collapse;\"\u003e\n\u003ctr\u003e\n\u003ctd style=\"padding:15px\"\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eInvestors, airlines, cruise operators, and newsletter writers who miss their work sweaters were watching President Trump for any news of a stimulus measure to cushion the economic impact of the coronavirus. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cul style=\"margin-top:0;padding-left:30px\"\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\u003cspan\u003eOf course, the most important thing is to contain the virus’s spread. But...that’s for health experts, not economists. \u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003c/ul\u003e\r\n\u003ch2 style=\"font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:19px;font-weight:700;color:#000;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;margin-right:0;margin-left:0\"\u003eWhat Trump said\u003c/h2\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eIn a brief Oval Office address last night, President Trump laid out \u003ca href=\"https://www.nytimes.com/2020/03/11/world/coronavirus-news.html?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003ehis plan\u003c/a\u003e to respond to the crisis: \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cul style=\"margin-top:0;padding-left:30px\"\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\u003cspan\u003eHe's restricting some travel from Europe (minus the U.K.) for 30 days.\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\u003cspan\u003eThe IRS will be instructed to push back the April 15 tax payment deadline.\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\u003cspan\u003eThe president also called for low interest loans for small businesses and a payroll tax cut from Congress. \u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003c/ul\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eInvestors were...not impressed. Futures tied to major stock indexes tanked after the speech, which did not mention any aggressive actions like infusions for suffering industries or paid sick leave. The White House also had to correct some of Trump's statements following his address.  \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eZoom out: \u003c/strong\u003e\u003ca href=\"https://www.nytimes.com/2020/03/11/business/dealbook/coronavirus-bailouts.html?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003eThere is precedent\u003c/a\u003e for government bailouts in times of crisis. The U.S. government provided $15 billion to airlines after 9/11, $700 billion to banks to army-crawl through the 2008 financial crisis, and $17 billion to automakers just after that. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cul style=\"margin-top:0;padding-left:30px\"\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\u003cspan\u003eThose episodes show us that timeliness is key. In 2008, Congress dragged its feet until it was almost too late, friend of the Brew and bailout expert Andrew Ross Sorkin writes. \u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003c/ul\u003e\r\n\u003ch2 style=\"font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:19px;font-weight:700;color:#000;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;margin-right:0;margin-left:0\"\u003eWill the administration announce something more?\u003c/h2\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eWe just don’t know. Fed Chair Jerome Powell recently met with President Trump and Treasury Secretary Steve Mnuchin. Powell has already cut interest rates and indicated he’s willing to keep up the slashing.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eBut it’s important to remember a pandemic is different from a financial crisis—bargain-basement interest rates can help keep businesses afloat, but the “social distancing” measures recommended by health officials mean canceling events and avoiding crowded places, which will curb spending. Interest rates can’t fix that. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eLooking ahead...\u003c/strong\u003ethe U.S. House will vote on a stimulus package compiled by the Democrats (who hold a majority) today.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c!-- SOCIAL LINKS --\u003e\n\u003ctable width=\"100%\" cellpadding=\"0\" collapse;\"\u003e\n\u003ctr\u003e\n\u003ctd style=\"padding:15px\"\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eYesterday, sports officially stopped being an \"escape\" from the problems facing the world.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eThe NBA \u003ca href=\"https://www.espn.com/nba/story/_/id/28887560/nba-suspends-season-further-notice-player-tests-positive-coronavirus?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003esuspended the season\u003c/a\u003e after Rudy Gobert, a Utah Jazz player, reportedly tested positive for coronavirus. In a statement, the league said it \u003cspan\u003e\"will use this hiatus to determine next steps for moving forward in regard to the coronavirus pandemic.\" \u003c/span\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cul style=\"margin-top:0;padding-left:30px\"\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\u003cspan\u003e\u003cspan\u003eWe're in \u003ca href=\"https://www.cbssports.com/nba/news/coronavirus-update-nba-suspends-season-after-utah-jazz-player-tests-positive-for-covid-19/?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003euncharted territory\u003c/a\u003e here. The NBA has billions in revenue at stake through TV deals, ticket sales, merch, and more. No one is quite sure what's going to happen next, including commissioner Adam Silver. \u003c/span\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003c/ul\u003e\r\n\u003ch2 style=\"font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:19px;font-weight:700;color:#000;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;margin-right:0;margin-left:0\"\u003eBasketball couldn't catch a break\u003c/h2\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eThe NCAA men’s and women’s basketball tournaments will be played \u003ca href=\"https://www.cnbc.com/2020/03/11/ncaa-march-madness-basketball-games-will-be-closed-to-public-spectators.html?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003ewithout public fans\u003c/a\u003e this year out of coronavirus concerns. “Only essential staff and limited family attendance” will be allowed, said NCAA President Mark Emmert.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eZoom out: \u003c/strong\u003eThe Division I men’s basketball tournament generates $868 million annually on \u003ca href=\"https://www.foxbusiness.com/sports/coronavirus-ncaa-basketball-revenue-march-madness-impact?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003etelevision and marketing rights alone\u003c/a\u003e, the vast majority of the NCAA’s yearly revenue. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cul style=\"margin-top:0;padding-left:30px\"\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\u003cspan\u003eCBS and Turner Sports said they support the decision and intend to fully produce and cover the event.\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003c/ul\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eBottom line, via USA Today: \u003c/strong\u003e“The decision to move March Madness behind closed doors represents a \u003ca href=\"https://www.usatoday.com/story/sports/ncaab/2020/03/11/ncaa-tournament-fans-banned-due-to-coronavirus-concerns/5024027002/?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003enew frontier\u003c/a\u003e of sorts for American sports, which have never seen an event of this size and scope take place without fans present.”\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c!-- SOCIAL LINKS --\u003e\n\u003ctable width=\"100%\" cellpadding=\"0\" cellspacing=\"0\" border=\"0\" style=\"border-collapse: style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eAfter 11 years, the longest-ever bull market in stocks appears to be nearing the end. If coronavirus put it near the edge, fears over \u003ca href=\"https://www.nytimes.com/2020/03/11/business/stock-market-today.html?action=click\u0026module=Spotlight\u0026pgtype=Homepage\u0026utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003elong-term economic implications\u003c/a\u003e tipped it over.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eYesterday, the Dow fell 5.9%, \u003ca href=\"https://www.wsj.com/articles/global-markets-calmer-after-two-hectic-days-11583899913?mod=breakingnews\u0026utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003eputting it in a bear market\u003c/a\u003e (down at least 20% from its recent high). The S\u0026P 500 might not be far behind, closing just 33 points away from a bear designation of its own.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eHow about a little color? \u003c/strong\u003eHope you like red. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cul style=\"margin-top:0;padding-left:30px\"\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\u003cspan\u003e29 of the 30 stocks in the Dow ended Wednesday lower. \u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\u003cspan\u003eAll 11 sectors of the S\u0026P were at least 10% off their 52-week highs during Wednesday trading. \u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\n\u003cspan\u003eSince 1915, the \u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e\u003ca href=\"https://twitter.com/ReformedBroker/status/1237323133109047296?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003eaverage amount of days\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e it’s taken for stocks to go from peak → bear territory is 255. The Dow took 28 this time. We’ve had milk in the fridge for longer.\u003c/span\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003c/ul\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong collapse;\"\u003e\n\u003ctr\u003e\n\u003ctd style=\"padding:15px\"\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eColleges and universities across the U.S. are \u003ca href=\"https://www.axios.com/universities-close-coronavirus-73fb30be-126d-4553-a0fc-8ae1f1d96ccd.html?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003edeploying measures\u003c/a\u003e to limit the spread of coronavirus. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cul style=\"margin-top:0;padding-left:30px\"\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\u003cspan\u003eFor many students, spring break starts tomorrow, which means many of them will be traveling both domestically and internationally. Schools are trying to avoid importing COVID-19 via flights back to campus.\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003c/ul\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eOn Tuesday, Harvard \u003ca href=\"https://www.axios.com/what-happens-when-harvard-closes-3652393f-6b99-4869-bef1-1b22765410e5.html?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003easked students\u003c/a\u003e to move out by this weekend, leaving students pondering how to tell friends they’ve been kicked off campus without sounding obnoxious. Stanford and the University of Washington were among the first to suspend in-person classes. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cul style=\"margin-top:0;padding-left:30px\"\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\u003cspan\u003eUW shifted its 50,000 students to online-only courses through March 20, as many schools in Europe and Asia have already done. \u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003c/ul\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003ePlus, schools are axing university-sponsored international trips, sending mildly alarming preparedness messages, and preparing for total shutdowns if a student or faculty infection is confirmed.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eBottom line: \u003c/strong\u003eMuted activity in college towns could take a substantial economic toll. Everything from prospective student visits to athletic tournaments fuels their financial health, \u003ca href=\"https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2020-03-10/college-towns-to-clear-out-with-virus-upending-local-businesses?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" width=\"100%\" cellpadding=\"0\" cellspacing=\"0\" border=\"0\" style=\"border-collapse: collapse;\"\u003e\n\u003ctr\u003e\n\u003ctd style=\"padding:15px\"\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eThe global entertainment market, from the box office to in-home streaming, surpassed $100 billion in annual revenue for the \u003ca href=\"https://variety.com/2020/digital/news/global-entertainment-industry-surpasses-100-billion-for-the-first-time-ever-1203529990/?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003efirst time ever\u003c/a\u003e last year, according to the Motion Picture Association of America (MPAA). \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eBut like \u003cem\u003eLes Mis\u003c/em\u003e, the MPAA report highlights the differences between the \u003ca href=\"https://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/fueled-by-streaming-global-entertainment-market-hit-record-100-billion-2019-1283800?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003ehaves and the have-nots\u003c/a\u003e.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cul style=\"margin-top:0;padding-left:30px\"\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\u003cspan\u003eMoney spent on home and mobile viewing jumped 14% to $58.8 billion. \u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\u003cspan\u003eBut the box office barely eked out a 1% gain with $42.2 billion in sales. While overseas moviegoers turned out in record numbers (crossing $30 billion in ticket sales for the first time), sales in the U.S. and Canada fell over 4% to $11.4 billion.\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003c/ul\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eThe forecast this year? Another case of red and black. With coronavirus fears spreading across the globe, \u003ca href=\"https://www.axios.com/global-entertainment-market-record-36bef1b3-68cf-49c0-a0be-f611d5dccd11.html?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003eout-of-home entertainment\u003c/a\u003e will likely take a beating—analysts already predict the box office will lose $5 billion in 2020. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eAt the same time, in-home entertainment is predicted to skyrocket even further...because we all know “working from home” roughly translates to “rewatching \u003cem\u003eThe Sopranos\u003c/em\u003e.”\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c!--
